items.name: Accessibility.Requirement
items.summary:
A requirement defining how the visual presentation of text achieves
a minimum contrast ratio to pass the accessibility specification -
https://www.w3.org/TR/2008/REC-WCAG20-20081211/#visual-audio-contrast-contrast

syntax.content: public enum Requirement

items.name: Minimum
items.summary:
The visual presentation of text has a contrast ratio of at least
4.5:1 (Level AA) -
https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/quickref/?versions=2.0#qr-visual-audio-contrast-contrast

syntax.content: Minimum = 0

items.name: MinimumLargeText
items.summary:
The visual presentation of large text has a contrast ratio of at
least 3:1 (Level AA) -
https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/quickref/?versions=2.0#qr-visual-audio-contrast-contrast

syntax.content: MinimumLargeText = 1

items.name: Enhanced
items.summary:
The visual presentation of text has a contrast ratio of at least
7:1 (Level AAA) -
https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/quickref/?versions=2.0#qr-visual-audio-contrast7

syntax.content: Enhanced = 2

items.name: EnhancedLargeText
items.summary:
The visual presentation of large text has a contrast ratio of at
least 4.5:1 (Level AAA) -
https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/quickref/?versions=2.0#qr-visual-audio-contrast7

syntax.content: EnhancedLargeText = 3

items.name: Accessibility
items.summary: Functions for testing color accessibility requirements.

syntax.content: public static class Accessibility

items.name: MinimumContrastRatio(Accessibility.Requirement)
items.summary:
Returns the minimum contrast ratio needed to pass compliance of a
given accessibility requirement.

syntax.content: public static float MinimumContrastRatio(this Accessibility.Requirement requirement)

parameters.description: The requirement to check.

return.description: The minimum contrast ratio needed to pass the requirement.

items.name: IsCompliant(Accessibility.Requirement, Color, Color)
items.summary:
Determines if the contrast between a foreground color and a
background color is compliant to the accessibility requirement.

syntax.content: public static bool IsCompliant(this Accessibility.Requirement requirement, Color foreground, Color background)

parameters.description: The requirement to check.
The foreground color.
The background color.

return.description: True if the contrast is compliant, false otherwise.

items.summary:
Determines if the contrast between the foreground color and a
background color is compliant to a given accessibility requirement.

syntax.content: public static bool IsCompliant(this Color foreground, Color background, Accessibility.Requirement requirement)

parameters.description: The foreground color.
The background color.
The requirement to check.

return.description: True if the contrast is compliant, false otherwise.

items.name: ColorModel
items.summary:
A color model is an abstract mathematical model describing the ways
colors can be represented as tuples of numbers, typically as three or
four values or color components.

syntax.content: public enum ColorModel

items.name: Hex
items.summary:
A representation of the RGB color model using hexadecimal numbers,
i.e., `#0080ff`.

syntax.content: Hex = 0

items.name: RGB
items.summary:
The RGB (red, green, blue) color model, an additive color mixing,
device-dependent model used mainly for the representation and
display of images in digital formats.

syntax.content: RGB = 1

items.name: RYB
items.summary:
The RYB (red, yellow, blue) color model, a traditional model used in
a standard artist's color wheel, particularly in painting.

syntax.content: RYB = 2

items.name: CMYK
items.summary:
The CMYK (cyan, magenta, yellow, black) color model, a subtractive
color mixing model used in color printing.

syntax.content: CMYK = 3

items.name: HSB
items.summary:
The HSB (hue, saturation, brightness) color model is an alternative representation to the RGB color model designed to more closely align with the way human vision perceives color-making attributes. HSB is the same as HSV.
The HSB representation models the way paints of different colors mix together, with the saturation dimension resembling various shades of brightly colored paint, and the brightness dimension resembling the mixture of those paints with varying amounts of black or white paint

syntax.content: HSB = 4

items.name: HSV
items.summary:
The HSV (hue, saturation, value) color model is an alternative representation to the RGB color model designed to more closely align with the way human vision perceives color-making attributes. HSV is the same as HSB.
The HSV representation models the way paints of different colors mix together, with the saturation dimension resembling various shades of brightly colored paint, and the value dimension resembling the mixture of those paints with varying amounts of black or white paint

syntax.content: HSV = 5

items.name: HSL
items.summary:
The HSL (hue, saturation, lightness) color model is an alternative representation to the RGB color model designed to more closely align with the way human vision perceives color-making attributes.
The HSL model attempts to resemble more perceptual color models such as the natural color system (NCS) or Munsell color system, placing fully saturated colors around a circle at a lightness value of ​½, where a lightness value of 0 or 1 is fully black or white, respectively.

syntax.content: HSL = 6

items.name: HSI
items.summary:
The HSI (hue, saturation, intensity) color model is an alternative representation to the RGB color model designed to more closely align with the way human vision perceives color-making attributes.
The HSI model commonly used for computer vision, which takes H as a hue dimension and the component average I ("intensity") as a lightness dimension, does not attempt to "fill" a cylinder by its definition of saturation. Instead of presenting color choice or modification interfaces to end users, the goal of HSI is to facilitate separation of shapes in an image.

syntax.content: HSI = 7

items.name: CIE
items.summary:
The CIE color spaces were the first defined quantitative links
between distributions of wavelengths in the electromagnetic visible
spectrum, and physiologically perceived colors in human color
vision. The mathematical relationships that define these color
spaces are essential tools for color management.

syntax.content: CIE = 8

items.name: YCbCr
items.summary:
The YCbCr color model used as a part of the color image pipeline in
video and digital photography systems. Y is the luminance (luma)
component and Cb and Cr are the blue-difference and red-difference
chrominance (chroma) components, respectively.

syntax.content: YCbCr = 9

items.name: YPbPr
items.summary:
YPbPr is the analog version of the YCbCr color space; the two are
numerically equivalent but YPbPr is designed for use in analog
systems while YCbCr is intended for digital video.

syntax.content: YPbPr = 10

items.name: YUV
items.summary:
YUV is a color encoding system typically used as part of a color
image pipeline. It encodes a color image or video taking human
perception into account, allowing reduced bandwidth for chroma
components, thereby typically enabling transmission errors or
compression artifacts to be more efficiently masked by human
perception than using a "direct" RGB-representation.

syntax.content: YUV = 11

items.name: YIQ
items.summary:
YIQ is the color model used by the NTSC color TV system, intended to
take advantage of human color-response characteristics. The chroma
component I stands for *in-phase*, while chroma component Q stands
for *quadrature*, referring to the used in quadrature amplitude
modulation.

syntax.content: YIQ = 12

items.name: ColorSpace
items.summary:
A color space is a specific organization of colors. In combination with
physical device profiling, it allows for reproducible representations of
color, in both analog and digital representations. Adding a specific
mapping function between a color model and a reference color space
establishes a definite "footprint", known as a gamut, and for a given
color model this defines a color space.

syntax.content: public enum ColorSpace

items.name: sRGB
items.summary:
sRGB (standard Red Green Blue) is an RGB color space that HP and
Microsoft created cooperatively in 1996 to use on monitors,
printers, and the Internet. It is often the "default" color space
for images that contain no color space information, especially if
the images' pixels are stored in 8-bit integers per color channel.

syntax.content: sRGB = 0

items.name: CIERGB
items.summary:
In the 1920s, W. David Wright and John Guild independently conducted
a series of experiments on human sight, from which they tried to
determine the colors in human vision, and give it a mathematical
basis. The results of these experiments defined the CIE 1931 RGB
color space which became the basis for the trichromatic CIE 1931 XYZ
color specification.

syntax.content: CIERGB = 1

items.name: CIEXYZ
items.summary:
In 1931, based on the results of the CIE RGB version of the human eye, CIE mathematically determined a theoretical color space called the CIE 1931 XYZ color space to map out all of the colors perceived by the human eye. It is considered to be one of the most accurate color spaces; thus, it is commonly used for color management and conversions.
X, Y and Z are extrapolations of RGB created mathematically to avoid negative numbers and are called Tristimulus values. Y means luminance, Z is somewhat equal to blue, and X is a mix of cone response curves chosen to be orthogonal to luminance and non-negative.

syntax.content: CIEXYZ = 2

items.name: CIExyY
items.summary:
In CIE xyY, Y is the luminance and x and y represents the
chromaticity values derived from the tristimulus values X, Y and Z
in the CIE 1931 XYZ color space. CIE xyY is just another way to
represent CIE 1931 XYZ.

syntax.content: CIExyY = 3

items.name: CIEUCS
items.summary:
The CIE 1960 UCS color space is another name for the (u, v)
chromaticity space devised by David MacAdam. The CIE 1960 UCS does
not define a luminance or lightness component. Today, the CIE 1960
UCS is mostly used to calculate correlated color temperature, where
the isothermal lines are perpendicular to the Planckian locus.

syntax.content: CIEUCS = 4

items.name: CIEUVW
items.summary:
The CIE 1964 U\*V\*W\* color space is based on the CIE 1960 UCS.
Wyszecki invented the UVW color space in order to be able to
calculate color differences without having to hold the luminance
constant. He defined a lightness index W\* by simplifying
expressions suggested earlier. The chromaticity components U* and V*
are defined such that the white point maps to the origin. This
arrangement has the benefit of being able to express the loci of
chromaticities with constant saturation.

syntax.content: CIEUVW = 5

items.name: CIELAB
items.summary:
CIE 1976 L\*a\*b\* is a color space in which L is lightness and a
and b are chromaticity components, with the difference that the
color values are far more than the human gamut. It was designed to
be perceptually uniform with respect to human color vision, meaning
that the same amount of numerical change in these values corresponds
to about the same amount of visually perceived change.

syntax.content: CIELAB = 6

items.name: CIELUV
items.summary:
The CIE 1976 L\*u\*v\* color space is a simple-to-compute
transformation of the CIE 1931 XYZ color space, but which attempted
perceptual uniformity. It is extensively used for applications such
as computer graphics which deal with colored lights.

syntax.content: CIELUV = 7

items.name: CIELCh
items.summary:
The CIELCh° color space is a cylindrical representation of the CIELAB or CIELUV cube color space, where C* is the chroma and h° is the hue. The L* lightness value remains unchanged.
The LCh color space is not the same as the HSV, HSL or HSB color models, although their values can also be interpreted as a base color, saturation and lightness of a color. The HSL values are a polar coordinate transformation of what is technically defined RGB cube color space. LCh is still perceptually uniform.

syntax.content: CIELCh = 8

items.name: HunterLab
items.summary:
The Hunter Lab color space, defined in 1948 by Richard S. Hunter, is another color space sometimes referred to as "Lab". Like CIELAB, it was also designed to be computed via simple formulas from the CIE 1931 XYZ space but to be more perceptually uniform than CIE 1931 XYZ.
Hunter named his coordinates L, a, and b; the CIELAB space, defined years later in 1976, named its coordinates L*, a*, and b* to distinguish them from Hunter's coordinates.

syntax.content: HunterLab = 9

items.name: LMS
items.summary:
LMS (long, medium, short), is a color space which represents the response of the three types of cones of the human eye, named for their responsivity (sensitivity) peaks at long, medium, and short wavelengths.
The numerical range is generally not specified, except that the lower end is generally bounded by zero. It is common to use the LMS color space when performing chromatic adaptation (estimating the appearance of a sample under a different illuminant). It's also useful in the study of color blindness, when one or more cone types are defective.

syntax.content: LMS = 10

items.name: ColorVision
items.summary: A type of color vision.

syntax.content: public enum ColorVision

items.name: Normal
items.summary: Normal color vision.

syntax.content: Normal = 0

items.name: Protanopia
items.summary:
Protanopia is a blindness to red, a state in which the red cones are
absent.

syntax.content: Protanopia = 1

items.name: Protanomaly
items.summary:
Protanomaly is a reduced sensitivity to red, a result of
functionally limited red cones.

syntax.content: Protanomaly = 2

items.name: Deuteranopia
items.summary:
Deuteranopia is a blindness to green, a state in which the green
cones are absent.

syntax.content: Deuteranopia = 3

items.name: Deuteranomaly
items.summary:
Deuteranomaly is a reduced sensitivity to green, a result of
functionally limited green cones.

syntax.content: Deuteranomaly = 4

items.name: Tritanopia
items.summary:
Tritanopia is a blindness to blue, a state in which the blue cones
are absent.

syntax.content: Tritanopia = 5

items.name: Tritanomaly
items.summary:
Tritanomaly is a reduced sensitivity to blue, a result of
functionally limited blue cones.

syntax.content: Tritanomaly = 6

items.name: Achromatopsia
items.summary:
Achromatopsia is a condition characterized by a total absense of
color vision.

syntax.content: Achromatopsia = 7

items.name: Achromatomaly
items.summary:
Achromatomaly is a condition characterized by a partial absense of
color vision.

syntax.content: Achromatomaly = 8

items.name: Harmonies
items.summary: Functions for generating color harmonies.

syntax.content: public static class Harmonies

items.name: Monochromatic(Color, Int32, Single)
items.summary:
Creates a monochromatic harmony of the color, a set of tints and
shades formed from the base color.

syntax.content: public static Color[] Monochromatic(this Color baseColor, int amount = 5, float difference = 0.25F)

parameters.description: The base color to create the harmony from.
The number of colors to create.
The amount of change in each color.

return.description: An array of colors forming the harmony.

items.name: MonochromaticNonAlloc(Color, Color[], Single)
items.summary:
Creates a monochromatic harmony of the color, a set of tints and
shades formed from the base color. The colors are stored in an
existing array to prevent heap allocations. The amount of colors
generated is determined by the size of the array.

syntax.content: public static void MonochromaticNonAlloc(this Color baseColor, Color[] output, float difference = 0.25F)

parameters.description: The base color to create the harmony from.
The output array to store the colors in.
The amount of change in each color.

items.name: Analogous(Color, Int32, Single)
items.summary:
Creates an analogous harmony of the color, a set of colors located
next to each other on the color wheel.

syntax.content: public static Color[] Analogous(this Color baseColor, int amount = 3, float hueShift = 30F)

parameters.description: The base color to create the harmony from.
The number of colors to create.
The amount of degrees to shift each hue.

return.description: An array of colors forming the harmony.

items.name: AnalogousNonAlloc(Color, Color[], Single)
items.summary:
Creates an analogous harmony of the color, a set of colors located
next to each other on the color wheel. The colors are stored in an
existing array to prevent heap allocations. The amount of colors
generated is determined by the size of the array.

syntax.content: public static void AnalogousNonAlloc(this Color baseColor, Color[] output, float hueShift = 30F)

parameters.description: The base color to create the harmony from.
The output array to store the colors in.
The amount of degrees to shift each hue.

items.name: Complementary(Color)
items.summary:
Creates a complementary harmony of the color, two colors located
opposite to each other on the color wheel.

syntax.content: public static Color[] Complementary(this Color baseColor)

parameters.description: The base color to create the harmony from.

return.description: An array of colors forming the harmony.

items.name: ComplementaryNonAlloc(Color, Color[])
items.summary:
Creates a complementary harmony of the color, two colors located
opposite to each other on the color wheel. The colors are stored in
an existing array to prevent heap allocations. The array requires a
size of at least 2.

syntax.content: public static void ComplementaryNonAlloc(this Color baseColor, Color[] output)

parameters.description: The base color to create the harmony from.
The output array to store the colors in.

items.name: SplitComplementary(Color)
items.summary:
Creates a split complementary harmony of the color, the base color
with two colors adjacent to the directly opposing color on the color wheel.

syntax.content: public static Color[] SplitComplementary(this Color baseColor)

parameters.description: The base color to create the harmony from.

return.description: An array of colors forming the harmony.

items.name: SplitComplementaryNonAlloc(Color, Color[])
items.summary:
Creates a split complementary harmony of the color, the base color
with two colors adjacent to the directly opposing color on the color
wheel. The colors are stored in an existing array to prevent heap
allocations. The array requires a size of at least 3.

syntax.content: public static void SplitComplementaryNonAlloc(this Color baseColor, Color[] output)

parameters.description: The base color to create the harmony from.
The output array to store the colors in.

items.name: DoubleSplitComplementary(Color)
items.summary:
Creates a double split complementary harmony of the color, two pairs
of complementary colors on either side of the base color.

syntax.content: public static Color[] DoubleSplitComplementary(this Color baseColor)

parameters.description: The base color to create the harmony from.

return.description: An array of colors forming the harmony.

items.name: DoubleSplitComplementaryNonAlloc(Color, Color[])
items.summary:
Creates a double split complementary harmony of the color, two pairs
of complementary colors on either side of the base color. The colors
are stored in an existing array to prevent heap allocations. The
array requires a size of at least 4.

syntax.content: public static void DoubleSplitComplementaryNonAlloc(this Color baseColor, Color[] output)

parameters.description: The base color to create the harmony from.
The output array to store the colors in.

items.name: Triadic(Color)
items.summary:
Creates a triadic harmony of the color, three colors evenly spaced
around the color wheel to form a triangle (120° hue shifts).

syntax.content: public static Color[] Triadic(this Color baseColor)

parameters.description: The base color to create the harmony from.

return.description: An array of colors forming the harmony.

items.name: TriadicNonAlloc(Color, Color[])
items.summary:
Creates a triadic harmony of the color, three colors evenly spaced
around the color wheel to form a triangle (120° hue shifts). The
colors are stored in an existing array to prevent heap allocations.
The array requires a size of at least 3.

syntax.content: public static void TriadicNonAlloc(this Color baseColor, Color[] output)

parameters.description: The base color to create the harmony from.
The output array to store the colors in.

items.name: Square(Color)
items.summary:
Creates a tetradic (square) harmony of the color, four colors evenly
spaced around the color wheel to form a square (90° hue shifts).

syntax.content: public static Color[] Square(this Color baseColor)

parameters.description: The base color to create the harmony from.

return.description: An array of colors forming the harmony.

items.name: SquareNonAlloc(Color, Color[])
items.summary:
Creates a tetradic (square) harmony of the color, four colors evenly
spaced around the color wheel to form a square (90° hue shifts). The
colors are stored in an existing array to prevent heap allocations.
The array requires a size of at least 4.

syntax.content: public static void SquareNonAlloc(this Color baseColor, Color[] output)

parameters.description: The base color to create the harmony from.
The output array to store the colors in.

items.name: MixingModel
items.summary:
A model that describes how colors are mixed together to form all other
colors.

syntax.content: public enum MixingModel

items.name: Additive
items.summary:
A mixing model that leads to the RGB color model with primary colors
of red, green, and blue. The absence of color is black, and the
presence of all three primary colors is white. Colors are added
together to form white. Additive color mixing simulates light.

syntax.content: Additive = 0

items.name: Subtractive
items.summary:
A mixing model that leads to the CMYK color model with primary
colors of cyan, magenta, and yellow. The absence of color is white,
and the presence of all three primary colors is black. Colors are
subtracted to form black. Subtractive color mixing simulates print.

syntax.content: Subtractive = 1

items.name: Traditional
items.summary:
A mixing model that leads to the RYB color model with primary colors
of red, yellow, and blue. The absence of color is white, and the
presence of all three primary colors is black. Traditional color
mixing simulates paint.

syntax.content: Traditional = 2
